abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Primary Education
            Project's outcome is rated as satisfactory,
            sustainability as highly likely, institutional development
            impact as modest, Bank performance as satisfactory, and
            borrower performance as satisfactory. The sharp devaluation
            of Mexican peso in 1994-95 led to a reduction in project
            costs, which in turn led to a partial cancellation of the
            Bank loan in 1995 and a complex project restructuring
            exercise which was successfully completed in 1997. As a
            result, project objectives were expanded and two new
            components were added. The key lessons learned include: A
            clear and consistent policy framework is key to the
            achievement of project objectives. Project ownership and
            continuous participation of stakeholders greatly enhance
            project design and implementation. Effective targeting is
            essential to optimize the impact of compensatory programs.
            Precise output indicators should not obviate the need for
            outcome indicators. The results of the measurement of
            education quality must be analyzed and disseminated.
            Updating teaching skills through in-service training can be
            more effective when combined with classroom-based technical
            assistance. Community participation greatly improves the
            cost-effectiveness of school infrastructure investments but
            requires appropriate design and technical supervision.
            Community agreements for the maintenance of school buildings
            need to be properly funded.

18218725.subsc: Sub-natl govt admin,Tertiary education,Primary education,Central government administration
18218725.theme: Education for all,Social analysis and monitoring,Indigenous peoples,Decentralization

abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Primary Education Project
            consists of three major components: the human resources
            development component will provide in-service training and
            assistance to upgrade the skills of primary school teachers,
            principals, and supervisors, emphasizing the role of
            principals and supervisors in providing pedagogical
            assistance to teachers in classroom teaching. The
            educational material resources component will: (a) provide
            educational materials for both teachers and students; (b)
            supply classroom library and reference books and promote
            their use; (c) design and deliver bilingual textbooks and
            material for indigenous schools; and (d) rehabilitate,
            replace, or build urgently needed educational facilities to
            replace inadequate schools and meet new enrollment demand.
            The institutional strengthening component will: (a)
            strengthen education management capacity at both central and
            state levels by: (i) providing management training for
            planning and policy analysis; (ii) installing project
            monitoring, evaluation, and information systems; (iii)
            conducting education studies to prepare future investments
            at the preschool and secondary education levels; and (iv)
            supporting project promotion and diffusion activities; (b)
            provide incentives for teachers to work in remote
            indigenous, or hardship areas; (c) improve the supervision
            system; and (d) strengthen the textbooks and materials
            distribution system.
